competencies.name: Driver  shows the required Certificate of Professional Competence (CPC)
Driver  shows the ADR driver training certificate
Driver/Operative identifies the different types of clinical/healthcare waste using the standard colour-coding containment system
Driver/Operative demonstrates proper caution and care  when dealing with clinical/healthcare wastes which may be hazardous
Driver/Operative matches different types of clinical/healthcare waste to the relevant EWC documentation code
Driver  displays the correct transport (hazard) plates on the outside of the vehicle, as  applicable
Driver/Operative  has obtained or received suitable preventative vaccinations for specified infectious diseases
Driver/Operative  wears the correct personal protective clothing when handling clinical/healthcare wastes
Driver carries waste transfer documentation where required
Driver/Operative  checks that sacks are correctly sealed before handling or transfer and takes remedial action where necessary
Driver/Operative  carries/lifts loose sacks by the neck to minimise the potential for cross-contamination or injury
Driver/Operative demonstrates procedure for dealing with leaking containers containing clinical waste
competencies.supportingText:
1. What would you do if you found an infectious clinical waste container that was leaking?
  2. Where is the ADR/Spillage kit located on your vehicle?

competencies.name: Driver/Operative visually checks the bin contains the same types of waste (i.e. not mixed waste types) before transfer to the collection vehicle (wheeled bin collections only)
Driver/Operative checks that all wheeled bins are locked before securing the vehicle

Driver/Operative  picks up sharps or rigid containers using handles provided and carries out a visual inspection for correct closure before loading onto the collection vehicle (loose waste collections only)
Driver/Operative  can state internal procedure for reporting non-conformances
Driver/Operative  ensures any cut or abrasion is suitably cleaned and covered before starting the handling process
competencies.supportingText:
1. If you had a cut on your hand, what action would you take before starting your collections?
  2. What are the potential risks of not covering an open wound when dealing with soiled/infectious materials?

competencies.name: Driver/Operative  reports any injury, accident or near miss as per company procedure
competencies.supportingText:
1. What would you do if you injured your leg when moving some rigid waste containers?
  2. What is the company procedure for reporting accidents?

competencies.name: Driver/Operative  competently operates the tail-lift function on the vehicle (if present)
Driver/Operative  correctly completes Duty of Care documentation prior to waste leaving the site and leaves a signed copy for the producer
Driver/Operative locates spillage kit
Driver/Operative initiates and completes the appropriate spillage procedure in the event of a container leaking or splitting
Driver/Operative selects the correct items in the kit to safely clean up spillage
Driver/Operative selects or uses additional personal protective equipment required to prevent cross-contamination
Driver/Operative carries out the spillage procedure in the event of a liquid or solid waste spillage
Driver/Operative contains the spillage for safe onward handling and transfer
Driver/Operative reports spillage (and action taken) to supervisor and assists in completing a non-conformance report
competencies.supportingText:
1. What is the company procedure for reporting spillages?
  2. Why is it important to investigate the causes of a clinical waste spillage?

competencies.name: Driver/Operative  contacts the relevant authorities in the event of a spillage/accident on a public highway
competencies.supportingText:
1. Who would you inform in the event of a spillage or vehicle accident?
    2. Why is it important to investigate the causes of a clinical waste spillage?

competencies.name: Driver/Operative correctly identifies the range  of sharp implements that may be present in the clinical/healthcare waste streams
competencies.supportingText:
1. Give some examples of sharp objects that may be found in the clinical/healthcare waste stream.
  2. What type of container should be used to contain sharps?
  3. Are sharps generally considered to be infectious or non-infectious?

competencies.name: Driver/Operative selects the correct equipment to safely handle loose sharps
Driver/Operative selects and uses additional personal protective equipment required to prevent cross-contamination or needle-stick injury
Driver/Operative uses correct range of colour-coded containers to correctly contain contaminated sharps
Driver/Operative correctly contains sharps for safe onward handling and transfer
Driver/Operative implements  the local procedure for dealing with a needle-stick injury
competencies.supportingText:
1. Describe how you would treat yourself or a colleague who had received a needle-stick injury.
  2. What action would you take if you received a sharps injury at the collection (producer) site?

competencies.name: Driver/Operative implements the procedure for completing an accident form in the event of sharps injury
competencies.supportingText:
1. Who would you report a needle-stick injury to in the first instance?
  2. Where is the company accident book located?
  3. Who is responsible for co-ordinating the reporting of accidents and incidents in your company?

competencies.name: Driver/Operative reports sharps injury/non-conformance (and action taken) to supervisor and assists in completing relevant reports
competencies.supportingText:
1. What information do you need to provide to your supervisor for the report?
  2. How do you think needle-stick injuries can be avoided in the future?
